title: Queensland drops lockout laws in favour of mandatory ID scans
text:
Licensing laws Queensland drops lockout laws in favour of mandatory ID scans 
Annastacia Palaszczuk says the reduced trading hours already in place will ‘reduce the level of violence across our state’ The state government says it has been ‘listening to Queenslanders’ in decided to ditch plans for a 1am lockout. Photograph: Glenn Hunt/Getty Images   08.31 GMT Last modified on   08.33   Share on Messenger Close 
The Queensland government will scrap its lockout laws in exchange for a deal with pubs and clubs to run mandatory identification scanning to enforce bans on selected patrons. 
The premier, Annastacia Palaszczuk , said on Monday her cabinet had decided to drop its proposed 1am lockout because reduced trading hours already in place would “reduce the level of violence across our state”. 
The decision came despite an independent report on the first six months of earlier nightclub closures finding the effects on violence levels had been “blurred” because of some venues “abusing the system”, Palaszczuk said. 'Nightlife is still alive and well': do critics have it wrong on Sydney's lockout laws? Read more 
But Palszczuk said she had been “listening to Queenslanders” and that “many women” had been raising safety issues with her about “travelling home on public transport in the early hours of the morning”. 
She said forcing venues that trade past midnight to have identification scanners, which copy details of every patron entering, was “good policy”. 
A Deakin university report, commissioned by the government, found that the “widespread and systematic” use of extended trading hour permits to 5am had undermined the impact of 3am closures in nightclub precincts. 
Because of this, there had not been a single weekend since last July where all venues in Brisbane’s Fortitude Valley had stopped serving alcohol at 3am, it said. 
“The current research evidence suggests that the introduction of lockouts (one-way doors) is not likely to significantly change current trends (except for pre-drinking),” the report said. 
A mandatory scanning network for late-night venues in the state’s main entertainment precincts was already due to take effect next month alongside the lockout. 
The network, by which venues would share information on patrons banned for violence or what clubs consider misbehaviour, would operate via a database that only “approved operators” of licence scanning systems, and not clubs themselves, could broadly access. 
Guardian Australia can reveal that one of only two government-approved custodians of this data on banned patrons is part-owned by a former internet business operator whom the federal court found guilty of misleading and deceptive conduct in 2004. 
Scantek Solutions Pty Ltd, which will transmit information to scanners at venues flagging when a banned patron seeks entry, lists Chesley Paul Rafferty as a director and shareholder – holding 16% of ordinary shares and 34% of employee shares – according to company searches. 
Rafferty was taken to court by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission over conduct by his web domain names business. 
The court found Domain Names Australia, and Rafferty as its sole director, breached the Trade Practices Act by sending businesses invoices demanding payment to renew registration of their domain names, when they were actually paying to register a slightly different name. 
The Deakin university report found there had been “no obvious reduction in alcohol-related assaults” in nightclub precincts or across Queensland since July. 
Nor had there been any “significant change in injury presentations at emergency departments during high alcohol hours”, it said. 
But since the government’s changes, there had been a “continuing downward trend in common and serious assaults” between 8pm and 6am statewide, as well as an ongoing drop in common assaults in Fortitude Valley between 3am and 6am. 
The Deakin report concluded that restricted trading hours needed to be “actuated” for the governments “last drinks” policy to be effective. 
“It is very important to note that there has been virtually no fidelity to the last-drinks at 3am in [nightclub precincts] across Queensland due to the systematic and widespread use of extended trading permits,” it said. 
It suggested changes to extended trading hours permits, which are expected to be used for occasions such as New Year’s Eve. 
“The lack of change in alcohol-related harms during earlier hours also indicates that measures used to reduce harm earlier in the night such as ID scanners, and banning orders for repeat offenders continue to be warranted,” the report said. 
Palaszczuk in response said the government would cut the number of extended trading permits from 12 to 6. 
She said that “some of the data that has been collected is blurred, because some people have been abusing the system”. 
“We need good factual data where people are not misusing the permits,” she said. Queensland lockout laws: millionaire offers to bankroll campaign to end them Read more 
The government’s backflip on the lockouts followed calls from both the Liberal National opposition and the Queensland Greens, to make a decisive ruling and scrap the proposal altogether rather than postpone it. 
Palaszczuk said the decision came after “extensive discussions” within cabinet. “The first major part of our reforms have been introduced and are law in this state,” she said. “By reducing the trading hours of the service of alcohol, we can reduce the level of violence across our state.” 
Ministers including the lockout laws’ chief proponent, former facial surgeon Anthony Lynham, had earlier talked down the significance of a lockout, saying earlier closing times already put in place by the government were most important in reducing violence.
